thread.title: Farmers pleased to see WA's Gascoyne River flow
thread.title_full: Farmers pleased to see WA's Gascoyne River flow

author: Matt Brann
title: Farmers pleased to see WA's Gascoyne River flow
text:
Map: Carnarvon 6701 
To the excitement of locals and relief of farmers, Western Australia's longest river, the Gascoyne River, has pushed through to the coastal farming town of Carnarvon. 
The river reached Nine Mile Bridge yesterday afternoon, in what is the first decent flow in almost two years. 
Fruit and vegetable grower Michael Nixon said it was great news for farmers and has excited the entire community. 
"It's just awesome," he told ABC Rural after seeing the river for himself. 
"I think all of town has lined up on the river banks to watch it come in, it's always a bit of a spectacle in a town like this where it doesn't rain." 
Mr Nixon said the river had the potential to fix a number of irrigation issues facing growers. 
"Since the 2010 floods , the biggest thing that happened, was the end of that water which came down was quite salty and infected a lot of the aquifer," he said. Rural news in your inbox? Subscribe for the national headlines of the day. 
"What we need, and what we've been wishing for this river for ages, is a nice, gently 1.8-2 metre river, which is exactly what this is, and have it flow for about a month or ideally more. 
"That would refresh a lot of our aquifers and fix a lot of problems. 
"Since 2010, there have been some farmers here that haven't been able to pump because of the salty water deposited in front of their farm." 
Mr Nixon said farmers were hoping the Department of Water would soon declare free-pumping, allowing farmers to get hold of surface water. 
"If you can stick a big pump in and start getting it out it make s a big difference, we could get a month's work done in a week," he said. Gascoyne cattle stations enjoying a good start to 2017 
Upstream from Carnarvon, Gascoyne cattle producers are also enjoying the sight of a flowing river. 
"It's a very nice sight to wake up to and see that big water-trough [the river] filling up," said Waddy Robinson from Doorawarrah Station. 
"Last year was a pretty poor result through this neck of the woods, we only had three-and-a-half inches of rain (88.9millimetres) and that was on top of a pretty similar amount the year before. 
"So we've been hanging out for a bit this year and so far it's been pretty good, we're up to about 48 millimetres so far and the river is flowing."
